text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to have Thai kitchen last week 
I showed you a basic recipe for traditional Pad

Thai and this week I'm going to show you some 
things you can do to switch things up a bit so

we're going to do three different variations 
we're going to do two sauce variations and

one noodle one and then in the end I'm going to 
make one crazy pot Thai using all three different

variations let's get started so the basic peptide 
sauce as we saw last week is a simple combination

of palm sugar fish sauce and tamron right and 
that yields a brown color dish now you might

be wondering what about the orange colored Pad 
Thai what's in there well if you see that in

North America it could be a number of things 
could be ketchup tomato paste or paprika and

they just do that to boost a nice color through 
you see that in Thailand and it's a good place

chances are it's shrimp tomalley or what we call 
shrimp fat now shrimp tomalley is basically the

orange stuff inside the shrimp heads you can 
see it from the outside lobster has the same

thing you can squeeze it right other the shrimp 
heads and add it to your Pad Thai or you can buy

it in a jar like this now this entire week all 
mango and Pad Thai that uses this in the dish

it's called Taemin goon and this already has some 
seasoning and whatever a little bit of salt some

garlic just some stuff and to use this you just 
add about a tablespoon of it to the basic sauce

now this is called shrimp paste with soybean 
oil at least this brand labels it like that

but don't confuse this with this shrimp paste 
this is fermented shrimp paste that we've used

this before in curry paste right we add about a 
teaspoon of this in our curry paste not the same

thing very different cannot be substituted all 
right now shrimp paste on mango is actually the

liver of the shrimp so it's kind of like shrimp 
foie gras so if you want to add a little color

and extra umami flavor and a little extra 
fat to your pad thai go ahead and add this

the second sauce variation is to add something 
called si Racha which is this guy more commonly

known as sriracha which is this guy now this 
is the original hot sauce that was made in the

town of Si Racha in Thailand and this is the 
product that inspired the more commonly known

rooster sauce that's popular in America now or 
all over the world actually to add this it'll

add a little spiciness add a little acidity so 
when I incorporate this into my peptide I like

to cut back a little bit on the tamron so maybe 
a tablespoon less of tamarin and then make up

the difference in Si Racha if you can't find 
this one you can definitely use this one but

bear in mind that this is spicier more acidic 
and less sweet so I tend to use a little less

of this one and of course you can always add 
this at the end but it's definitely an option

for you to add it to the sauce while you're 
making it and finally a final variation is

a noodle variation this is a very common way 
to have pad thai in Thailand most places that

sell Pad Thai will also offer something called 
pad thai wooden sin which is pad thai made with

Winson and when sin is glass noodles we've 
seen it in young Winston before comes in a

package like this and this is what it looks 
like when it's dry now to use this you just

soak it in water about 15 minutes until it's 
soft and it's usually very long so you'd want

to cut it don't cut it too short but I usually 
want to cut it once or twice just to you know

so it's not so hard to eat drain it off for 
the recipe that I gave you last week you

will only need 80 grams of it because it does 
expand a lot more and now we're going to make

a crazy batch of pad thai I'm going to use all 
three things that we talked about I'm going to

use shrimp paste si Racha and I'm also going to 
use wouldn't send let's go see what that's like

the base of our sauce is the same as last week 
we've got some palm sugar dissolved in water

fish sauce but this time we're cutting back 
on the tamron and making it up with Si Racha

chilli sauce add our shrimp tamale and it's 
ready to go the cooking process is similar

to the basic recipe so let's just go through it 
quickly you want to first cook your shrimp set

them aside and then in the same pan we're going 
to cook some garlic shallots dried shrimp sweet

preserved radish chili flakes and pressed tofu 
in ghosts are a wooden sending and now is the

part that's a bit different you want to add a 
quarter cup of water and then the sauce keep

tossing and turning until the glass noodles have 
absorbed all the sauce taste the noodles and see

if they're still too chewy if so you can add a 
little more water at this point push the noodles

over to one side and add the eggs scramble 
the eggs just slightly and then let them set

a bit put the noodles on top of the eggs and 
let the eggs cook and flip it up break the

eggs up a bit and then add bean sprouts garlic 
chives and half of your peanuts mix it all up

and it's done okay let's plate it now believe 
it or not I have never actually done this all

three variations all in one dish until now so we 
have done them separately I've just never done it

all together like this so you are witnessing my 
first time so we'll find out together how this

is I'm sure it's good I just want to know how 
good yay okay extra peanuts extra Chili's oh

yes garnish why not a bunch of lime I mean the 
traditional was good but this is good so please

give this a try start with the original from 
last week if you miss that I'll put the link

to last week's video in the description here 
and then please if you get a chance we can

find ingredients move on to this one it's so good 
for the written recipe of this one you can also

check out hot eye-catching calm and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
